content: The "Small Business Incentive Act of 1993" amends the Securities Act of 1933 to increase the exemption threshold from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000 and excludes certain securities from the definition of an investment company. Section 3(c) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to deem certain issuers as investment companies for specific limitations regarding the purchase and sale of securities issued by registered investment companies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify certain issuers as investment companies based on ownership of securities by qualified purchasers, with specific limitations on purchasing securities from registered investment companies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify certain issuers as investment companies based on ownership of securities by qualified purchasers, with specific limitations on purchasing securities from registered investment companies, including section 12(d)(1) governing the purchase or acquisition of securities. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify certain issuers as investment companies based on ownership of securities by qualified purchasers. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to define a "qualified purchaser" as a person who owns a significant amount of securities in non-affiliated issuers. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to define a "qualified purchaser" as a person who may own or invest a lesser amount in securities than specified in subparagraphs (A) and (B), that the Commission has determined does not need the protections of this title, after considering factors such as financial sophistication, net worth, assets owned, relationship with an issuer, and other relevant factors. The Commission may adopt rules and regulations for persons specified in subparagraphs (A) and (B) as deemed necessary for the public interest and investor protection. SEC. 5 amends the definition of investment securities in the Investment Company Act of 1940. SEC. 6 provides an exemption for economic, business, and industrial development companies. Section 6(a) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include a new paragraph stating that companies not issuing redeemable securities and regulated by the state can provide financial or managerial assistance for economic development within the state. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to allow companies regulated by the state to provide financial or managerial assistance for economic development within the state, with specific requirements for the sale of securities to accredited investors residing in the state. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to allow companies to sell securities only to accredited investors as defined by the Securities Act of 1933, with restrictions on purchasing securities issued by investment companies unless they are rated investment grade by a recognized organization. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment allows the sale of securities to accredited investors, with restrictions on purchasing securities unless they are rated investment grade by a recognized organization or issued by an open-end investment company investing at least 65% in similar quality securities. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment allows the sale of securities to accredited investors, with restrictions on purchasing securities unless they are rated investment grade by a recognized organization or issued by an open-end investment company investing at least 65% in similar quality securities. Companies described in a specific paragraph must comply with certain provisions as if they were registered investment companies. Companies intending to rely on an exemption must file a notification with the Commission. Companies meeting the requirements can rely on the exemption until the Commission determines otherwise. The Commission may allow companies to rely on an exemption until deemed not in the public interest or investor protection. Additional terms and conditions may be imposed as necessary. SEC. 7 amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 to change the exemption amount to $10,000,000 or as determined by the Commission. SEC. 8 defines an eligible portfolio company. SEC. 8 amends the definition of eligible portfolio company under the Investment Company Act of 1940 by setting limits on total assets and capital. SEC. 9 amends the definition of business development company under the Investment Company Act of 1940 to exclude the requirement of providing significant managerial assistance to certain types of companies. SEC. 10 addresses the acquisition of assets by business development companies. SEC. 10 amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 regarding the acquisition of assets by business development companies. It allows companies to acquire assets from any person, subject to regulations set by the Commission. Section 61(a) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to change the asset coverage requirements for business development companies. The new requirement is 200 percent, but a company can have a coverage of at least 110 percent under certain conditions. The Investment Company Act of 1940 has amended the asset coverage requirements for business development companies to be 200 percent, with the option for a coverage of at least 110 percent under specific conditions. Business development companies must meet certain criteria regarding their assets and investments to comply with the new regulations. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amended asset coverage requirements for business development companies to 200 percent, with an option for 110 percent coverage under specific conditions. Business development companies are prohibited from issuing senior securities representing indebtedness without adequate asset coverage. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amended asset coverage requirements for business development companies to 200 percent, with an option for 110 percent coverage under specific conditions. Business development companies are prohibited from issuing senior securities representing stock without adequate asset coverage. It shall be unlawful for any business development company to issue any class of senior security representing stock without provision to prohibit the declaration of any dividend. The provision prohibits business development companies from declaring dividends or distributions on common stock without maintaining at least 110 percent asset coverage for senior securities. Compliance with subparagraph (B)(i) is required, except for amounts necessary for distribution maintenance. The provision prohibits business development companies from declaring dividends on common stock without maintaining 110 percent asset coverage for senior securities, except for amounts required for distribution to comply with regulatory requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments include changes to paragraphs regarding senior securities and indebtedness. The provision allows business development companies to issue warrants, options, or rights for voting securities without accompanying securities, under certain conditions. Business development companies can issue warrants, options, or rights for voting securities if authorized by shareholders or partners and approved by the required majority of directors or general partners. SEC. 12. FILING OF WRITTEN STATEMENTS. Amendment to the Investment Company Act of 1940 to include "and capital structure" after "portfolio".
